article: Mikio Tanaka is a devoted father----and prove it by taking three months off to care for his baby boy. That makes Tanaka _ of a revolutionary in Japan, where men are _ known for working long hours and _ in the bars with clients than mixing baby milk and changing diapers . "It was _ , but it was also a lot of fun," Tanaka said, sitting _ the living room floor with his 4-month-old son, Daiki, _ on his back. " I saw the first time he stood up . It was a great experience." Tanaka, 31, is one of a _ number of fathers in Japan who are taking a bigger _ inside the home. Men are a _ sight with kids at parks and zoos at weekends, though often _ yawning. Books and magazines _ fathers on how to play with and care for their kids. For Japan's _ housewives, the changing is too late. In Tanaka's case, his wife, Ayako, 28, was _ to take a full year of leave , for she was a school teacher. _ for Tanaka, a department chief at his company had taken the _ leave a few years before, so his plan to _ three months unpaid leave was not a total shock to his _ . Ayako took three months off for Daiki, then it was Tanaka's _ when she went back to work. Daiki started day care full-time at _ month. Tanaka said at that time he was able to work again.
